title: Before 27 July 2019, how many candidates who participate at the first Democratic presidential primary debates scheduled for 26-27 June will cease to be candidates?
preds:
One candidate has dropped out. 
The base rate for dropping out of a race 3 days before a debate is low.
Of low polling candidates Williamson has declined It's possible that party insiders prevail on some candidates at the last minute but unlikely since the rules will weed out candidates before the 4th debate.

Category is for one or two.  One:
Swalwell already dropped out. 
https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2019/07/08/eric-swalwell-first-2020-candidate-drop-out/1671930001/ Two:
Delaney's staff asked him to drop out. He may be next most likely, but was selected for the second debate, so is unlikely to drop out before then. 
https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/john-delaneys-team-asks-him-to-drop-out-of-2020-race Runner up for two:
Maybe someone random will do it.  Three: 
Not likely until after this next debate.

Passage of time. Also FYI, some good arguments here, e.g. minor candidates still having a chance to break out (dampening any reasons to drop out at this stage): https://thehill.com/hilltv/rising/453971-democratic-strategist-predicts-most-2020-candidates-will-drop-out-in-late-fall
A few will drop out, but not many this early in the process.

Profs to Cafebedoin's crew for this find - these are my flags and indicators of movement on the subject - “I don't think [candidates] decide to get out: It's decided for them: when their money dries up, when they can't pay their staff, they can't pay for travel. If they're wealthy like Tom Steyer, I guess that doesn't matter. But we're not even there yet, because we haven't even had the second debate. They're looking for their moment that they are 'made'—and then, when that's over, reality is going to sink in with them, their staffers and their donors. That's what creates the psychology that the press and the pundits and the donors 'don't know what I know. I know how to win. I've done it before. They were all wrong before.' And it's hard to argue with that. So they continue running until they run out of fuel." – Larry Sabato, University of Virginia Center for Politics
also looking for news of a big donor get together. Thats were they'll decide what to tell who. Then it will happen. Often it involves Donor B going to Donor A and saying - lets pay off so and so's debt and push this guy out front.
There are only 7 days left to the 27th. One has already suspended his campaign. Yesterday, a new Twitter campaign for another to drop out began.
Getting closer and only 1 out so far...
Nobody will bail out who has a seat at the next debate.  Probably be some winnowing after that, perhaps a lot.  Try not to be surprised if this question's successor pops up again pretty soon.
I wager no one will drop out until after the debates
There are too many in the race
One of 2 will drop out as a matter of course but it's too early for many to drop out.
As no candidates have dropped out at this stage, it is very unlikely they will do so with mere 9 days until the deadline.
Not clear yet what approach will defeat Trump (women vote, ant-racist, impeachment strategy)
They won't get sufficient funding to continue
best guess know little about us politics
I think one has already dropped out in this time period, but there isn't much time left for others to drop out before the deadline you have set.
Not all have sufficient donors. I think they are down to 21 and the next round is 20, rather than be disqualified I think 3-4 will graciously bow out
Not even the candidates can be so stupid or egotistical as to think a divided field can beat Trump
The current field is unsustainable, with many candidates running out of money and not getting much support at all.
Its a bit of a guess

They would have no reason to stop their campaign. As we have seen in the past, polls are deceptive, and only once the primaries start will we have clearer picture who the main candidates will be. Some might withdraw for personal reasons though.

With nine days to go to the next debate, there is no point for any of the original candidates to drop out. They've all been given spots in debate 2. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-debate/bullock-joins-second-2020-democratic-debate-rest-of-candidates-the-same-idUSKCN1UC2RQ

As soon as one drops out, the others all think they're going to win.  It takes a while for reality to sink in, and it usually sinks into donors and staff before the candidate catches on.  For a while, refugees from the current clown car will leak out fairly slowly.  Sooner or later there will be a faster cascade, but not this soon.   Full disclosure:   Although I used to be impressively accurate on US politics, I have come apart in the last few years and so should be ignored on this topic.  Still, if you watch the flow of donations, it is likely to help you.
I think half will drop out
One has already dropped out.  With 9 days to go, it seems likely that another one or two may decide to pull out before September.
There are usually lots of candidates to begin with that get whittled down over time.
As the people will not vote for lesser personality cadidates

Working on the assumption that 1/4 of candidates will withdraw within the first couple of weeks. Some will not withstand media scrutiny and others recognise lack of profile lessens their chance of success. A further 5/6 will give way to party colleagues who are showing better traction and lend support to them. This should clear the field by half leaving the remaining 9 to be hit with scandal, family circumstance changes and withdrawal as a result of minimal chance of success.
Most candidates will be weeded out later in the process.
Some must go but not very many yet
I believe this to be the likelihood
Interest in the wisdom of crowds. Have used it in pricing in business.
There are 25 currently : https://qz.com/1536793/your-guide-to-the-2020-democratic-presidential-candidates/ and these will be whittled down evertually
Many have no chance and will not be able to raise funding to go further
I don’t think that in this short time period there is enough information for candidates to assess whether to stay in or drop out; also the top 5 are very close in the polls
The large number of candidates suggests a culling, but pride and self belief will limit this, so I expect to see a c. 20% drop out

This appears to be a very large pool of candidates, and I’d expect some consolidation as individuals realise they have limited prospects of success, and could support another candidate with similar values
Too early for people to drop out en masse
To ensure that the selection process is not too widely spread. Candidates may also identify with other candidates and they have the courage to withdraw. They may also identify stronger candidates.
Large pool of candidates that need to be narrowed down

Start with 20 candidates and there are likely to be those who will not progress to the September and October debates due to not meeting the thresholds. Some candidates will lose support as they are compared to the other candidates during the July debates.
It's the start of a long process
A lot of candidates know they probably have no chance but throw their name in there as a gesture and so they can use their influence to transfer their followers to their choice candidate
Most politicians won’t go at this early stage unless they have a total disaster
I understand there are lots of candidates, unlikely to be a few in that time.

Whilst it is very expensive to maintain a campaign and there is already a clear leading pack of 10 or so (see polls/ betting odds etc) only a few will drop out in the next week the rest hoping in vain that they can raise more money and accumulate support from others dropping out
There are too many candidates and based on polls quite a few will cease to be candidate to avoid humiliation.

There are 20 candidates. There is  chance of at least 1 candidate dropping out of the race in the first round is 100%.  remaining 19 will continue to the second round and here at least 10 will drop out. Of the remaining 8 three will not be able to gain the requisite votes.
Remaining 5 only 2 will make it to the final  stage.The reason for this is lack of capital to continue. Of the remaining  2 only 1 will be able to muster the confidence of the people and will be able to  carry forward  the campaign with financial and the investment made by him /her  in doing the requisite home work
We are close to the end date and a I am not aware that any have yet withdrawn, but, given that there are so many candidates, I think that there is a likelihood that a small number will withdraw.
The Democratic Party is fractured between centrists and far left candidates. However, financial support will start to be concentrated with probably 2 candidates from either camp.
There are too many candidates to think about. Decision paralysis will kick in. Human brain thinks 1,2,3,4.....lots. The number of candidates need to drastically reduce down before the public engage.
I believe it will be too early for too many candidates to withdraw at this stage. I think the number will increase as the process continues.
Only 10 days to go so unlikely to happen
Gut feeling and with only days to go there is little talk of it.
The number of candidates means that financial support for campaigns will be spread thinly. Those with lesser funding will realise that they cannot continue.
Previous history and last option has greater chance of being correct.
such a large field will slim down, but I doubt it'll really start to thin until August / September.
What has happened in previous years. Funding
One or two always drop out for funding or scandal reasons.
The hatred of that asshole trump is so great that people will stick in the fight longer than would normally be the case

Because candidates  who have entered the debate have done so for name recognition and advancement, to drop out so quickly afterwards would be admitting failure.  They will wait until resources become to few to continue.
20 candidates is too many to take forward in people's minds.
The first primaries give the candidates a taste for the process and a clear indication of their own standing with the public.  More a likely to leave then.
The first debate will only lead to a few hopefuls pulling it if at all as this is early in the race
It’s early in the race, it will take time before people start pulling out

https://www.vox.com/2019/7/15/20691651/democratic-debate-2019-cnn-detroit-candidates-rules offers a quick breakdown of the current qualifying candidates. It appears very unlikely 2 or more additional candidates will drop out in the next 10 days. Keeping an eye out for Delaney, Ryan, and Hickenlooper, but at this point why drop out? If they want to drop out and run in other races, they can use the stage to get their names out and create buzz before dropping out to run other races. I halved the probability of 3-4 candidates down to 8%. Very unlikely. Five or more has shrunk again significantly below 1%.
Those who didn't do well in the last debates may recognize the cost of continuing, and choose a graceful departure.
2 weeks to go. Swalwell out. Not aware of any others confirmed out. Expect half a dozen to drop out over next 6-8 weeks. Less certain of next 2 weeks.
NYC blackout may cause Di Blasio to drop out. But that still makes only two.
Swalwell is done.  The rules for the September debates are pretty stringent (130,000 donors and 2% in the polls, I believe) so only 5-6 will qualify for that.  Others will jump for want of money.

Welcome to The Hill’s Morning Report. 
 . . . 
"On the Democratic side, Senate Minority Leader Charles Schumer (D-N.Y.) still hasn’t given up hope that multiple lower-tier Democratic presidential candidates will drop out and run for Senate in key states on the 2020 map. 

"As Alexander Bolton reports, in the wake of Rep. Eric Swalwell’s (D-Calif.) decision to drop out of the presidential race, Schumer is hoping former Rep. Beto O’Rourke (D-Texas), Montana Gov. Steve Bullock (D) and former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper (D) will take the hint and launch Senate bids in their respective states, all of which could become tough, competitive races if they were to do so. Of the three contests, only one — Colorado — is expected to be considered a top-tier Senate contest as Sen. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.) is believed to be the most vulnerable Senate Republican up for reelection."

Can't state a reason just a sense that in such a group some factor, health, scandal, main supporting contributor pulls the plug, could happen to a couple or a few.   Someone will have to but there won't be a cluster of because a candidate wants even their exit to be remembered as an individual act and not as "the gang of three that quit in july" or something like that.
Most will have by now failed to raise enough money to satisfy the people who run the dem party so will be encouraged to help in other places.

It always gets too spendy to keep running
The top 5 or 6 donation earners will wildly outstrip everyone else, and only the billionaire types will stick it out (more for hubris than anything)  other candidates will start dropping to get back to focusing on their own current offices for re-election
There are a 25 candidates, who may stop for various reasons at various time periods. Eric Salwell has already withdrawn, so that's one.
Agree with @Anneinak. If you plan to eventually run for US Senate, may as well stay for the debate to publicize your name identification. So, I believe few will drop out before that date.

https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/08/us/politics/on-politics-eric-swalwell.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage " . . . Mr. Swalwell’s exit may be a harbinger for other ambitious politicians failing to make a dent in the 2020 race. Aides to former Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado recommended he drop out of the primary and challenge . . .  In Iowa Sunday, Mr. Hickenlooper, whose campaign recently lost some of its top staffers, acknowledged that running for president involves “a bunch of skills that don’t come naturally to me,” but vowed to stay in the race. He has until mid-March to enter the Senate race. Some Democrats have also urged Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana to run for Senate, hoping the popular governor could win an unlikely Democratic seat in a red state. He would also have until spring to make that decision. But in Texas, the filing deadline to challenge Senator John Cornyn, another potentially vulnerable Republican incumbent, is Dec. 9 — nearly two months before any primary votes are cast. And although Democrats have already recruited M.J. Hegar, a veteran who won attention for her 2018 congressional campaign, both Beto O’Rourke and Julián Castro are better known in the state, and both have been pushed to run for the seat. The remaining members of Congress in the 2020 race hail from states that have laws allowing them to pursue two offices at once. (New Jersey recently passed legislation permitting it, a bill know as “Cory’s Law.”) But just because some candidates can run for both offices doesn’t mean they should. In Hawaii, State Senator Kai Kahele is seeking Representative Tulsi Gabbard’s seat, telling Vice News that she has a “tiger on her tail, and she’s going to be in trouble.” In Massachusetts, a second woman announced on Monday that she’d be making a primary run for Representative Seth Moulton’s seat. At least five other Democrats have left the door open to jumping into the race. But don’t get too excited about the field shrinking quite yet. As Mr. Swalwell leaves, the California billionaire Tom Steyer plans to enter the race.
Eric Swalwell announced he is dropping out. https://www.google.com/amp/s/fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-eric-swalwells-campaign-failed/amp/

Per Politico [1], increasing >2 from 10%. “I’ve long believed it will winnow down substantially come Thanksgiving,” said Mike McCauley, a South Carolina-based strategist who worked on Barack Obama and John Kerry’s presidential campaigns. “I haven’t seen anybody to cause me to reconsider that. And if anybody is hanging on through Iowa outside the top six, we’re talking about a cabinet tryout or vanity.”  "Interviews with more than a half-dozen campaigns — none of which would go on record — and with dozens of other operatives, party officials and activists reveal an expectation that the upcoming debate in July will set in motion the initial culling of the 23-candidate field. Candidates who fall flat on the stage a second time, or fail to get traction, will see their finances dry up and be forced to exit. Those who fail to make the September debate — when the criteria for entry will be even higher than the first two debates — will be the next to go as their campaigns are denied the necessary oxygen to survive. Others are expected to retreat and prepare for reelection to their current elected positions after failing to gain traction by summer’s end." [1] https://www.politico.com/story/2019/07/08/2020-democratic-candidates-1399458

Adjusting values after the news of Swalwell's drop out.  0 is now 0%. Very likely Swalwell and possibly one more candidate will drop out (keeping an eye on Hickenlooper, although he has vowed to stay in the race; could be someone else or no one else). Looking this early in the past election seasons, typically candidates do not leave in droves at this stage. Looking at the month after the first debate there have been 0-2 drop outs in each presidential primary since 2004. Considering this, I raised the probability for 1-2 all the way to 83%.  I must admit, this strikes me as very high; however, every time I consider the alternatives - higher probabilities for 3-4 and 5+ candidates dropping out - I can't justify to myself that I should be raising those values more than I have. There being 1 drop out significantly improves the probability of 3-4 drop-outs - I'd say by a factor of 4x. While still unlikely, multiple longshot candidates might see this as an opportunity to leave gracefully (while not being the first to do so) especially with public/media perceptions of the fundraising numbers to be released this month. We must keep in mind though, that while that narrative makes sense, historically this has not been the case. Three or Four has made a large jump to 16%. Five or more is still exceedingly unlikely; however, I must admit it is significantly more likely with the news of Swalwell dropping out. Raised in probability to ~1%.
Updated based on Swalwell dropping out. While I didn't expect this, I don't see why any other candidates would want to drop out rather than participate in the second debate.
Eric Swalwell will hold a news conference on Monday afternoon.
After canceling his New Hampshire campaign swing over the weekend, Eric Swalwell will hold a news conference Monday afternoon.

I assume candidates give up due to severe campaign cash flow problems or to run for other offices (e.g. Senate, Governor). There are many long-shot candidates who already know they have little chance of winning so that is not a reason to quit at this point. I'm not aware of major financial problems or likely departures for other runs except for 1-2 candidates where this may happen, so my guess is a low (5%) probability. Could be wrong!
Too early in the race to drop out. All had something to crow abut in the first debate.

This isn't directly germane to the question, but in the least relevant story of the long July 4th weekend, some reporter points out that Bernie Sanders will not get the nomination this year, either. Yes, we all knew that. https://www.cnn.com/2019/07/02/politics/bernie-sanders-polls/index.html

https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/marianne-williamson-and-andrew-yang-make-next-2020-democratic-debate
Both Yang and Williamson and 12 others have qualified for the 2nd debate.

There are no particular relevant events scheduled before 27 July (at time of forecast only 22 days away). There is little campaigning (= costs) at present. Candidates tend to withdraw in the weeks before the first primary, not long before them. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_candidates#Withdrew_before_the_primaries

Hickenlooper? Bumping up the “one or two” category...
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hickenlooper/departing-advisers-urged-john-hickenlooper-to-quit-white-house-race-source-idUSKCN1TX2NF

Hedging again because of the Hickenlooper situation.  The conditions given by GJO stipulate that the candidate must withdraw from the contest, or suspend his or her campaign in order to be considered out of the race. So just being denied a spot in debate 2 would not mean that a person "ceased to be" a candidate. There would have to be a positive statement by a candidate saying, in effect, that they are no longer a candidate. I only think that will happen if the candidate has a viable alternative, and Hickenlooper may have one since he is considered (by some people, evidently) to have a shot at a Senate seat. None of the other no-hope candidates has any real reason to withdraw, since they probably don't have anything better to do anyway.

per Hill's Morning Report 7/3/2019 " Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper’s (D) campaign is facing major problems as many of his top staffers, including his campaign manager, communications director, digital director and finance director, have left or plan to leave in the near future, according to Politico.

Additionally, members of his senior staff have urged him to drop out of the presidential race as he fails to gain traction with primary voters and struggles with fundraising, including only $1 million raised in the second fundraising quarter, and to run for Senate against Sen. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.). The fundraising total is not only miles behind other presidential candidates but also on par with or behind some Democratic Senate and House candidates. Hickenlooper publicly blamed his departed staffers in an interview for his fledgling campaign.

“We thought it was time to make a change,” he told MSNBC’s Craig Melvin. “You know, these campaigns are long, hard campaigns and you don’t always get it right with the first team.”
 ~~~~~~ https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/03/us/politics/july-democratic-debate-participants.html ". . . A New York Times analysis of donor and polling data shows that as of Wednesday, seven candidates seeking the Democratic nomination are actively fighting for six slots in the coming debate, which again will be split over two nights, July 30 and 31.
. . . 
Seven additional candidates, six of whom took part in last week’s debates, have qualified only by one of two metrics — meeting the polling threshold — meaning they are on the bubble and the Democratic National Committee’s tiebreakers will come into play. At the moment, former Representative John Delaney of Maryland, former Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado and Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio appear to have an advantage over the other four. Each of them has at some point earned 2 percent support in a qualifying poll, which raises their polling averages. (For the purposes of the tiebreaker, the D.N.C. will average each candidate’s best three polls.) That leaves Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and Representative Eric Swalwell of California in a virtual deadlock. Mr. Bullock is the only candidate in this group who did not debate last week. All four men appear to have the exact same polling average: 1 percent. The D.N.C. anticipated that this might happen, and officials said that in the event of a tie, they would rank the candidates based on “the total number of polls in which each candidate received 1 percent or more support.” By our count, Mr. de Blasio has eight such polls, Mr. Bennet has six, Mr. Bullock has five and Mr. Swalwell has three. That’s why the results of polls released in the next couple of weeks will be so important to those candidates. Each will be hoping to increase his polling average, add another 1 percent result to his tally, or both.
. . . 
The 14 candidates who have locked in a spot on the July debate stage by qualifying through both donors and polling, in alphabetical order, are: former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.; Senator Cory Booker of New Jersey; Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind.; the former housing secretary Julián Castro; Representative Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii; Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York; Senator Kamala Harris of California; Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington; Senator Amy Klobuchar of Minnesota; former Representative Beto O’Rourke of Texas; Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont; Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts; the self-help author Marianne Williamson; and the former tech executive Andrew Yang. Who could get cut from the third debate? An even larger group of candidates is expected to be left off the stage for the third debate in September. The D.N.C. raised the qualification thresholds for it significantly. Candidates will need to have at least 130,000 donors and earn 2 percent support in at least four qualifying polls. And this time they will have to meet both standards to make the cut. Five of those seven — Mr. Biden, Mr. Buttigieg, Ms. Harris, Mr. Sanders and Ms. Warren — have routinely eclipsed 2 percent support in the polls and will presumably meet the polling requirement with ease. They are all but certain to earn a spot on the stage in September. A sixth, Mr. O’Rourke, also has a track record of achieving 2 percent or higher in the polls, but a pair of post-debate surveys this week had him at 1 percent. Mr. Yang’s campaign announced Monday that he had also exceeded 130,000 donors, making him the seventh candidate to do so. But Mr. Yang’s support in the polls has wobbled between 0 and 2 percent, and it is not clear whether he will achieve 2 percent four times in a two-month window. The D.N.C. has said that only polls publicly released between June 28 and Aug. 28 can be used to help candidates qualify for the September debate. That means all the candidates have started counting again from zero. Candidates like Mr. Booker and Ms. Klobuchar often poll at 2 percent and above and may very well reach the polling threshold. But they could struggle to get to 130,000 unique donors. For just about everyone else, both the polling and donor thresholds present a significant challenge. Just this week, Politico reported that Mr. Hickenlooper had only 13,000 donors. So, it would not be at all surprising if the September debate ends up featuring 10 candidates or fewer. “The new 130,000-donor debate threshold is designed to cut candidates like me from the running,” Mr. Castro wrote in an email to supporters days after the new debate qualification criteria were released. “But let me make one thing perfectly clear: I have never accepted defeat without a fight — and I have no intention of starting now.” At the moment, former Representative John Delaney of Maryland, former Gov. John Hickenlooper of Colorado and Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio appear to have an advantage over the other four. Each of them has at some point earned 2 percent support in a qualifying poll, which raises their polling averages. (For the purposes of the tiebreaker, the D.N.C. will average each candidate’s best three polls.) That leaves Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado, Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and Representative Eric Swalwell of California in a virtual deadlock. Mr. Bullock is the only candidate in this group who did not debate last week. All four men appear to have the exact same polling average: 1 percent. The D.N.C. anticipated that this might happen, and officials said that in the event of a tie, they would rank the candidates based on “the total number of polls in which each candidate received 1 percent or more support.” By our count, Mr. de Blasio has eight such polls, Mr. Bennet has six, Mr. Bullock has five and Mr. Swalwell has three. [What we learned from the first round of Democratic presidential debates.] That’s why the results of polls released in the next couple of weeks will be so important to those candidates. Each will be hoping to increase his polling average, add another 1 percent result to his tally, or both. Three more candidates — Mayor Wayne Messam of Miramar, Fla.; Representative Seth Moulton of Massachusetts; and former Representative Joe Sestak of Pennsylvania — do not appear to have qualified for the debate via donors or polling. Though there is still time for that to change, those candidates will face an uphill battle for a spot on the stage, even if they manage to qualify.
. . .
Thinking about it, I probably overreacted to the Hickenlooper story.

As of today (7/3), there are 14 candidates who have secured their spots for the second debate (see link) so they have every incentive to stay in at least until 7/30. Of the remaining six, Bullock may displace one of them but I don't see any reason for all six not to stay in at least until the debate (five because they will be participating and the sixth (again, assuming Bullock makes it) staying for a bit after the debate due to pride. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/03/us/politics/july-democratic-debate-participants.html

After news of the state of Hickenlooper's campaign ( https://www.politico.com/story/2019/07/02/hickenlooper-2020-campaign-1395051 ) I'm shifting 3% from "zero" to "one or two" and slightly raising "three or four" as well. 5 or more still appears to be <1% to my view.

Two things I hadn't thought of: staff jumping ship, probably to find jobs with other candidates (presidential or otherwise), thus leaving candidates with nobody to actually do the grunt work on their campaigns; and bottom-rung candidates deciding to pull out of the presidential campaign and seek offices which they have a more credible chance of winning. https://www.politico.com/story/2019/07/02/hickenlooper-2020-campaign-1395051

-Historical data (2016, '12, '08) with the exception of dem. candidates in 2016 in which no one withdrew within a month of the first debate
-Greater probability historically of candidates dropping out sooner when the first debate is later in the year
-More strict benchmarks to meet for the 3rd debate, and since only 20 candidates will be in the 2nd debate, those not in it will have a tough time qualifying for the 3rd
-4 dem. candidates would take a hit to their political reputation if they fail to move up in the coming weeks
Campaigns cost a lot of money in the US, and money talks both ways: if important backers renege or revoke their support -and I thnik that will happen- the consequences are immediate.
Based on the 2015 Republican field, it took a few months after the first debate for candidates to drop out

Since 2004, when the first official party debates are before September, there were no major withdrawals within 30 days after that debate. This initially led me to the following: 
- "Zero" with a very high probability (70%)
- "One or Two" with a moderately low probability (27%) as there tend to be 1-2 major withdrawals after the first official primary debates (when starting later in the year) that could be seen here
- "Three or four" withdrawals was exceedingly unlikely (3%) but if 1-2 withdrawals occurred, there could be 1-2 follow-on withdrawals
- Five or more was exceptionally improbable and rated as 0% 2nd quarter donation numbers are to be released (and compared) in mid July, and more candidates have qualified for the 2nd debate (one confirmed at this writing, multiple more may qualify by late July). The 3rd debate doubles the requirements on individual donors and polls. The 2nd debate is limited to 20 candidates; if the tiebreaker rules remove any candidates from the first debate, those candidates are unlikely to get the boost required to qualify for the 3rd debate.  As of June 11th, 7 candidates barely qualified for the first debate; while John Delaney and Bill De Blasio had highlights from the debate this was not true for all those "on the bubble" candidates. This leaves ~5 candidates in danger of being replaced in the next debate. Assuming it is unlikely but possible that any given "in-danger" candidate will be replaced AND drop out before July 27, I am starting with a flat 15% probability that any given one of them will be replaced. I arrived at:
Zero - 44.3%
One or Two - 53%
Three or Four - 2.6%
Five or More - < 0.01%

It's still so early, candidates typically last longer than July before dropping out. However, given the democratic field is so big, there is some chance that some might drop since they have almost no chance of winning.
The pool is too large and some of the candidates I already forgot their names
Adjusting zero up 5% and 1-2 down 5% for the possibility that the DNC could be successfully pressured to allow more than the twenty maximum if a new candidate qualifies.

Thanks to @Stark20 who called my attention to a 538 article which describes how some of the candidates in the first debate could get bumped out of the 2nd one.    This is the kind of question that I need to mull over because there's so many variables! https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/876866

Richard Ojeda has reportedly dropped out. However, he was not in the debates and so does not count. [1] I am reducing the distribution slightly seeing as how Williamson seems unfazed by what I would consider a bad debate performance. This is from June, 2015: *** Who gets left off that first debate stage? The NBC/WSJ poll measured 16 GOP candidates in our horserace question. The forecast question is on how many Democratic candidates will drop out of the race after the first Democratic Primary debate and before the second debate. According the RealClearPolitics, half of the 20 candidates have average poll numbers less than 1% [1].  It is hard to believe that most of them believe that there is a chance to become the Presidential nominee.  Most of these candidates are in the race to raise their political profiles - for a cabinet job or future political activities.   With this as the motivation, one would think that it is too early to drop out after one debate.  However, in the 2016 Republican primaries,  1 out of 17 candidates dropped out after the first debate (in mid September,  much latter than the current first debate)  [2].  Scaling this to the current crop of 20 Democratic candidates yields 1.2 dropouts (essentially still 1 dropout).   To keep the campaign going, one needs funds.  Sixteen of the 20 candidates reported their haul in the first quarter of 2019.  Each of them have more than one million dollars [3].  The other 4 candidates have declared their candidacy too late for the March reporting cutoff.  It looks like that they have enough money to keep going after the first debate. Each candidate have about 10 minutes in the debate to make an impression, I would not be surprised that there is a breakout performance in the first debate for one or two of the low polling candidates.  But the others will linger in obscurity.  If I were one of them, I would not drop out right away, hoping for a second chance in the next debate (July 30-31).  I would expect lots of dropouts after this date. I am basing my forecast with the 2016 Republican primary results. [1] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/
[2] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-the-republican-field-dwindled-from-17-to-donald-trump/
[3] https://www.businessinsider.com/how-much-money-2020-democrats-candidates-have-raised-fundraising-2019-4
Updating forecast from insights from others here. Scoring political points by staying in past political viability. History of previous primaries.
Short time span, it seems unlikely that more than one or two would drop out so soon.
Even those without a chance stick it out for name recognition in future.

Here, I am supplementing my base rate analysis (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/874330) with analysis of the 2017 GOP primary which is the closest analog out of the last 40 years with 17 candidates. Five candidates withdrew before the primaries began [1], 2 in September, 1 in November, and 2 in December. It is remarkable that all withdrawals took place relatively late in the year preceding the election. From that perspective a drop-out in July would be surprising. I am therefore lowering my distribution a little. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Republican_Party_presidential_primaries

It is a quess at this time.  There will be a few who make a pitiful gaffe and will not be hindered in their quest.  Those who drop out will have polls showing a very small base of support...i.e., in the 1 - 3 percent range.

The reference class here is % of candidates who drop out by a certain date in a presidential primary that features a large number of candidates. Fortunately, there is data available going back to 1980 [1] For candidate fields of 10 or more, the base rate is that 32% drop out before the Iowa caucuses (in February). If we assume that a drop out cannot happen before July (seems reasonable), then there are seven months from July of year X to Feb of year X+1 when a drop out can happen. If we then divide the 32% number equally across 7 months we get 4.5% of candidates who drop out per month. then out of the 20 Democratic candidates we’d expect one to drop out in the next month.  How about the standard deviation? I calculated it at 11 percentage points. 1 SD away from the average is a percentage of 42% and 2 SD away is 53%. Divide both by 7 months as before and we get 6% and 7.5%, or 1 and 2 (1.5 before rounding) to drop out. Therefore, we’d expect that in 95% of scenarios the number of candidates to drop out in the next month to be less than 2.  On the downside, 1 SD and 2 SDs equal 0.6 and 0.3 candidates to drop out.  Additionally, one has to account for the fact that the probability of dropping out rises as we get closer to Iowa. Therefore, my previous calculation, which assumes an equal probability of dropping out in July and in December for example, overestimates the probability of dropping out in the next month.  Qualitatively speaking I’d not expect a candidate to drop out that soon. For candidates who are unlikely to win and therefore may drop out, the incentive for staying in the race for now is pretty much the same as the incentive for joining in the first place (i.e. raise your profile). It might have to take a really embarrassing performance in the first debate for a candidate to decide to drop out. Counterarguments: the base rate data uses a limited number of data points. The candidate field size of 20 is outstanding from the historical record. For future analysis: look more closely at the drop out rates in the 2016 GOP primary which saw 17 candidates and is the closest historical analog. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/some-of-todays-candidates-probably-wont-make-it-to-iowa/
